problem_text:
M. R. Vaughan-Lee and J. Wiegold (Proc. R. Soc. Edinburgh Sect. A, 95 (1983), 215–221) proved that if a finite p-group G is generated by elements of breadth ⩽ n (that is, having at most p^n conjugates), then G is nilpotent of class ⩽ n^2 + 1; the bound for the class was later improved by A. Mann (J. Group Theory, 4, no. 3 (2001), 241–246) to ⩽ n^2 − n + 1. Is there a linear bound for the class of G in terms of n?
Ya. G. Berkovich
